awd_abstract_narration:
The day-long Computational Structural Bioinformatics Workshop will bring together researchers and students working on a diverse set of problems including biomolecular structure representation, prediction, and alignment, biomolecule interaction and docking, and data mining and analysis of structural and genomics data. At the core of all these endeavors is the goal to establish and explore the relationships between protein sequence, structure, and function. The workshop will be held on August 30, 2020 and will coincide with the 11th ACM Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics (ACM BCB). This award will support the development and dissemination of advances in computational structural bioinformatics, and will fund workshop registration for up to 20 undergraduate and graduate students who are co-authors of manuscripts or poster abstracts accepted for presentation and inclusion in the conference proceedings.


A main objective of this workshop is to provide a forum for undergraduate and graduate students, and especially students from under-represented groups in computer science and bioinformatics, to present ongoing work, and to exchange project ideas and facilitate collaborations across labs and disciplines. The workshop will include several sessions for oral presentations of accepted manuscripts, as well as two poster sessions during which students will have the opportunity to explain their projects and answer questions. A career and hot topics round table discussion will provide students the opportunity to learn from each other and discuss current research challenges and opportunities. A synopsis of the student discussion session will be disseminated to the workshop website after the conclusion of the conference. The workshop website is at https://csbw.cs.wwu.edu/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The project supported the participation of 52 US-based students and faculty, including 9 undergraduate and 6 graduate students as co-authors, 31 undergraduate and 4 graduate student participants, and 3 jr. faculty as researchers and co-authors. The workshop was held remotely via Zoom on September 21, 2020, and included 5 sessions, during which student co-authors presented fourteen manuscripts for their faculty-mentored research projects, and fielded questions. The themes for the 5 sessions were Cryo-EM, Machine-Learning Based Approaches, Protein Structure and Function, an Industry and Academia Panel, and Docking, Mutations, and Protein Binding. The workshop was organized and moderated by Filip Jagodzinski (Western Washington University) and Kevin Molloy (James Madison University).

The success of the workshop was evident from the lively question sessions, as well as the high turnout for the panel, titled "Industry and Academia Careers in Bioinformatics: Current Trends and Prospects for the Future." Forty-two participants interacted with the four panelists from industry and three universities, who discussed and shared career prospects and guidance for students and up-and-coming researchers.

The presented research included several manuscripts related to COVID, including the SARS-CoV-2 proteome and the Coronavirus Spike Protein, as well as computational and algorithmic advances related to Electron Microscopy, and applications of Machine Learning to elucidate and predict protein function, mutations, and protein conformational changes. In addition to all manuscripts being published in the main conference proceedings, three manuscripts that were extensions of the workshop papers were subsequently published in an issue of the journal Molecules.

The broader impacts of the workshop included the participation of 14 members from under-represented groups in computer science, among 11 universities, across biology, chemistry, and computer science. In addition to the panel, both undergraduate and graduate students benefited from the opportunity to learn about cutting-edge algorithmic developments in structural biology and computational advances employing state-of-the-art methods.


Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: Filip Jagodzinski
